data.title: When McKinsey Comes to Town: inside the murky world of business
data.meta_description: What do Sheryl Sandberg, William Hague, Sundar Pichai and Chelsea Clinton have in common? They all started out working for McKinsey. You’ve probably heard the n
data.text:
What do Sheryl Sandberg, William Hague, Sundar Pichai and Chelsea Clinton have in common? They all started out working for McKinsey. You’ve probably heard the name. It’s the US-based management consultancy for overachievers that advises other overachievers. For years it attracted the brightest and the best staff and clients, ranging from blue-chip companies to governments, because it convinced them that it was a “values-driven organisation” that “observes high ethical standards” and is dedicated to creating “positive, enduring change in the world”.

Recently, however, a different picture has emerged that is murkier, to put it mildly. For that we have to thank The New York Times, whose investigative reporters have uncovered evidence that reveal that the consultancy will work for almost anyone who agrees to
